case_name: National Steel Works Ltd., Bombay v. respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 544 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 544 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated July 1, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 58 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 1, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Incometax Reference No. 58 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellant is the National Steel Works Ltd., Bombay, a limited liability company, referred to as the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the National Steel Works Ltd., Bombay, a limited liability companypany, hereinafter referred to as the assessee,

facts.text: Assessee carried on the business of a Rolling Mill prior to the partition of the country in the territory now in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: carried on the business of a Rolling Mill prior to the partition of the companyntry in the territory number in Pakistan.

facts.text: After the Partition, assessee's registered office was shifted to Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: After the Partition, its registered office was shifted to Bombay.

facts.text: Assessee had a factory in Bombay for carrying on the business of a rolling mill.

anchor.surface_text: It had numberfactory there for carrying on the business of a rolling mill.

facts.text: Assessee was a member of the Steel Rolling Mills Association of India and received quota of scrap and steel from the Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: It was a member of the Steel Rolling Mills Association of. India and as such was receiving a quota of companyl and steel from the Government of India.

facts.text: Assessee entered into a partnership with K. P. Irani on September 29, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In order to utilise the companyl and steel so received, it entered into a partnership with one K. P. Irani who had put a factory in Bombay

facts.text: K. P. Irani had a factory in Bombay called the New Era Iron Steel Works but had no quota of steel and scrap.

anchor.surface_text: called the New Era Iron Steel Works but had numberquota of steel and companyl.

facts.text: Partnership agreement provided that partnership would continue so long as the quota system regarding steel continued in the Dominion of India or till expiry of the lease of factory premises.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement of partnership entered into between Irani and the assessee on September 29, 1948 provided that the partnership would companytinue so long as the, quota system

facts.text: Capital of the firm was subscribed by partners in equal shares.

anchor.surface_text: in the Dominion of India or till the expiry- of the then, lease of the factory premises, and that the capital of the firm would be subscribed by the partners in equal shares.

facts.text: Partnership agreement clause 12 provided for payment of Rs. 50 per ton on all steel received by partnership from the Company through Steel Re-Rolling Mills Association of India or Iron and Steel Controller.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraphs 12 and 13 of this agreement are of importance and are quoted below. In the companysideration of Company taking the said Mr. Irani as partner in the partnership it is agreed that a sum of Rs. 50/- per ton on all steel

facts.text: Profits of partnership after expenses and interest shared equally.

anchor.surface_text: received by the partnership from the Company, through the Steel Re-Rolling Mills Association of India, Calcutta or Iron and Steel Controller, Calcutta shall be paid to the Company by this partnership calculated every mouth, and after deducting all the other expense

facts.text: All quota of steel and scrap received by Company to be utilised solely for partnership business.

anchor.surface_text: All the quota of steel and companyl that Company may receive from the Iron Steel Controller, the Government of India and from the Provincial Iron Steel Controller, Bombay or from the Steel Re-Rolling Mills Association of India, Calcutta

facts.text: In 1954, assessee and Irani entered into an agreement modifying the 1948 agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, in 1954, the assessee and Irani entered into an agreement where by the terms of the agreement of September 29, 1954, were modified.

facts.text: Amended clause 12 reduced royalty to Rs. 25 per ton from 1st October 1953 on rollable materials up to 30.6.54, except semis and perfect billets at Rs. 10 per ton.

anchor.surface_text: IT IS HEREBY AGREED THAT in clause 12 of the Partnership Agreement dated 29.9.48, the Royalty by which is fixed at Rs. 50/- per ton shall be reduced in the manner following from 1st October, 1953. Royalty of Rs. 25/- per ton shall be charged from 1/10/53

facts.text: Mr. K. R. Irani agreed to pay lump sum of Rs. 60,000 as goodwill in consideration of waiving royalty on quota of re-rollable scrap materials after 30.6.54.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. K. R. Irani hereby agrees to pay a lump sum of Rs. 60,000. - a good-will in companysideration of waiving the Royalty from the partnership Account on the quota. of re- rollable scrap materials received after 30.5.54.

facts.text: Rs. 60,000 to be debited to Irani's capital account, bearing interest at 6% per annum from 1st July 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. K. R. Irani here agrees that the said amount of Rs. 60,000/- be debited to his capital account in the books of partnership, bearing interest at 6 per annum from 1st July, 1954.

facts.text: No royalty charged on rollable materials received after 30th June 1954.

anchor.surface_text: No Royalty will be charged on any kind of rollable materials received after 30th June, 1954, by the Company from the partnership.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer brought Rs. 60,000 to tax in assessing assessee's income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: In assessing the income-tax on the assessee, the Income-tax Officer brought the amount of Rs. 60,000/- mentioned in sub- cl.  d  of amended paragraph 12 of the agreement to tax.

facts.text: Assessee's appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner failed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner failed

facts.text: Assessee's appeal to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal failed.

anchor.surface_text: and so did its appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: On assessee's application, Income-tax Appellate Tribunal stated a case to High Court on whether Rs. 60,000 is revenue receipt liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: On an application by the assessee, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal stated a case to the High Court for the decision of the question whether the sum of Rs. 60,000/received by the assessee companypany from Irani is a revenue receipt and liable to Income-tax.

facts.text: Bombay High Court decided Rs. 60,000 is revenue receipt liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided that it was a revenue receipt and liable to tax.

facts.text: Appeal filed after obtaining certificate of fitness from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that this appeal has been filed after obtaining the certificate of fitness from the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant contends Rs. 60,000 was capital receipt for rights under quota possessed by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention for the appellant is that the sum of Rs. 60,000/- was paid by Irani to the assessee companypany in view of the partnership getting the rights under the quota which the assessee companypany possessed

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rs. 60,000 represents capitalised profits of assessee on account of transferring steel purchased under quota, hence revenue receipt.

anchor.surface_text: We do number agree. It is clear from the facts stated in the statement of the case that this amount represents capitalised profits of the assessee companypany on account of its transferring or selling the steel which the assessee companypany purchased, under the authority given by the quota allowed to it.

facts.text: Assessee purchases steel in its own name and delivers to partnership at cost price.

anchor.surface_text: It is the assessee companypany which purchases the goods in its own name and delivers them to the partnership at companyt price.

facts.text: No right to the quota itself transferred to Irani or partnership.

anchor.surface_text: No right, to the quota itself has been transferred to Irani or the partner ship under the agreement
This is an appeal under s. 66 A  2  of the Indian Income-Tax Act.

issues.text: whether the sum of Rs. 60,000/received by the assessee companypany from Irani is a revenue receipt and liable to Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: On an application by the assessee, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal stated a case to the High Court for the decision of the question whether the sum of Rs. 60,000/received by the assessee companypany from Irani is a revenue receipt and liable to Income-tax.

issues.text: whether the sum of Rs. 60,000/- was paid by Irani to the assessee companypany in view of the partnership getting the rights under the quota which the assessee companypany possessed and that therefore the sum represented a capital receipt and not a revenue receipt

anchor.surface_text: The companytention for the appellant is that the sum of Rs. 60,000/- was paid by Irani to the assessee companypany in view of the partnership getting the rights under the quota which the assessee companypany possessed and that therefore the sum represented a capital receipt and number a revenue receipt.

issues.text: whether the amount of Rs. 60,000/- represents goodwill

anchor.surface_text: The description of the amount as goodwill in companysideration of waiving royalty from the partnership account on the quota of re- rollable scrap materials received after June 30, 1954, does number companyvey the real nature of this amount and is really an expression which companyveys numbermeaning. There is numberquestion of goodwill in waiving a royalty.

arguments.claim: The sum of Rs. 60,000 was paid by Irani to the assessee in view of the partnership getting the rights under the quota possessed by the assessee and therefore represented a capital receipt and not a revenue receipt

anchor.surface_text: The contention for the appellant is that the sum of Rs. 60,000/- was paid by Irani to the assessee company in view of the partnership getting the rights under the quota which the assessee company possessed and that therefore the sum represented a capital receipt and not a revenue receipt.

arguments.court_reasoning: Amount represents capitalised profits from markup on steel supplied by assessee, no transfer of quota rights occurred, and goodwill label is meaningless

arguments.claim: The amount of Rs. 60,000 represents capitalised profits of the assessee on account of transferring or selling the steel purchased under the quota allowed to it

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the facts stated in the statement of the case that this amount represents capitalised profits of the assessee company on account of its transferring or selling the steel which the assessee company purchased, under the authority given by the quota allowed to it.

arguments.claim: The assessee purchases the steel in its own name and delivers it to the partnership at cost price

anchor.surface_text: It is the assessee company which purchases the goods in its own name and delivers them to the partnership at cost price.

arguments.claim: Rs. 50 per ton under original agreement represented profit which the assessee was getting per ton from the partnership

anchor.surface_text: Under the original agreement of 1948, the partnership was to pay to the assessee company Rs. 50/per ton on all steel it received from the assessee company. Clearly, therefore, the sum of Rs. 50/per ton represented the profit

arguments.claim: Rs. 60,000 represents the capitalised value of the profits the assessee was to have on supplying steel under its quota at net price

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the amended agreement, no such profit was to be paid to the assessee company for the steel received from it after June 30, 1954, and it was to receive Rs. 60,000/- in a lump sum. This amount, therefore, represents the capitalised value of the profits

arguments.claim: No right to the quota itself has been transferred to Irani or the partnership under the agreement

anchor.surface_text: No right, to the quota itself has been transferred to Irani or the partnership under the agreement

arguments.claim: The description of the amount as goodwill does not convey the real nature of the amount and there is no question of goodwill in waiving a royalty

anchor.surface_text: The description of the amount as goodwill in consideration of waiving royalty from the partnership account on the quota of re- rollable scrap materials received after June 30, 1954, does not convey the real nature of this amount and is really an expression which conveys no meaning. There is no question of goodwill in waiving a royalty.

arguments.claim: The sum of Rs. 60,000 received by the assessee from Irani is a revenue receipt and liable to income-tax

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided that it was a revenue receipt and liable to tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court conclusion correct as amount is capitalised revenue profits
